name: electricity production, hydro, reservoir, non-alpine region | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/9094/documentation

This dataset represents the production of high voltage electricity at grid-connected reservoir hydropower plants in Spain in 2012. Here, the reservoir hydropower plants are modelled with non-alpine region plants extrapolated from data on Swiss hydropower plants. A representative sample of various types of dams in Switzerland is taken into account, i.e. 52 reservoir power plants with a height of mor than 30 metres, an annual gross production output of 17.8 TWh and an installed capacity of 9130 MW.  As far as the construction is concerned, reservoir power plants and pumped storage power plants are dealt with together due to the fact that the construction efforts are related. Lifetime is assumed to be 150 years for the dam and 80 years for the rest of materials. The data refers to plant construction of a mix of types of dams built between 1945 and 1970; therefore they might not be representative for more modern construction, for an individual type and for small-scale and smallest-scale plants. ;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

This dataset starts from the power plant ready to produce electricity, i.e. the reservoir filled with water.
From (potential) energy in water, entering the power plant.

This activity ends with 1kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar. 

This dataset includes 
 - the area/volume occupied for the barrage, power station, and the lake
 - a preliminary estimation of emissions of methane
 - operation and maintenance activities and materials of the power plants, such as lubricating oil or mass of water passing through the turbines.


This dataset doesn"t include
 - land use for access roads to the reservoir
 - emissions of carbon dioxide and dinitrogen oxide
 - raw materials extraction, decommissioning and waste treatment as these activities are already included in the infrastructure datasets 
 - transformation of the electricity produced.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The Annual Production Volume is valid for the year 2012.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data were extrapolated from the average Swiss reservoir hydropower plant.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Storage power plants have an appendant reservoir. The size of the reservoir can range from daily, monthly to annual storage reservoirs. According to the net head high-pressure, medium-pressure and low-pressure systems can be distinguished. High- and medium-pressure systems are constructed as dams. High-pressure storage power plants with a head of over 50 meters are very common in Switzerland. For this dataset concrete dams (arch dams and gravity dams) with a height of more then 30 meters are taken into account. Also pumped storage power plants are included because in most cases the data is only available for the overall generation system. The same counts for high- and medium-pressure and alpine run-of-river power plants which are also included in the storage power plant dataset. Due to the fact that the efforts for the plant construction are similar to storage power plants and that the estimated production is comparatively low, high- and medium-pressure run-of-river power plants are covered by the reservoir power station dataset.;The technology used in the dataset has an overall efficiency of 82%, more modern technologies show an overall efficiency of about 88%. The overall efficiency is composed of the efficiency of the works water channel, the turbine, the generator and the transformer and are listed below:;Efficiency of power plant               current    modern;Works water channel	        0.95	     0.95;Turbine	                                        0.87	     0.91;Generator	                                        0.96      0.98;Transformer	                        0.98	     0.99;Reservoir power plant total		;without works water channel           0.82	     0.88;with works water channel                0.78	     0.84;Pumped storage power plant        0.70	    0.74;The losses along the works water channel are primarily caused by friction and are calculated from the difference between gross and net head. Based on this calculation the efficiency of the works water channel amounts to 95%. The losses depend on the flow rate and have its maximum at full load. The smaller the cross section of adits and pressure pipelines, the higher the flow velocity and thus the friction losses. In older plants according to Bischof (1992) the efficiency of works water channels could be increased generally more than by replacing turbines and generators.;The efficiency losses in turbines depend on the turbine type (Kaplan, Francis, Pelton, etc.), the turbine output and on the ratio between turbined water amount and the rated water amount. In König (1997) examples for curve progressions of the relationship between these variables are shown. For current power plants an efficiency of 87% is assumed, more modern turbines show an efficiency of about 91%.;The efficiency of generators depends on the output, the rotation speed of the generator and the cooling system. Some relevant data can be found in König (1997). For today’s power plants an efficiency of approximately 96% is assumed, modern generators show an efficiency of about 98%. The efficiency of transformers amounts to 98%, respectively 99%.;References:;Bischof, R. (1992) Modernisierungspotential bei bestehenden Wasserkraftwerken. Vortrag beim Schweizerischen Technischen Verband, Sektion Graubünden, 21. Oktober 1992. Churwalden, Schweiz [unpublished].;König F., von (1985) Bau von Wasserkraftanlagen. C.F. Müller, Karlsruhe.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from an original dataset covering the geography CH (Switzerland). The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Sampling procedure based on literature. Some information regarding the results is given without source notes or detailed, comprehensible derivation due to the guaranteed confidential treatment of data.

flow.name: electricity, high voltage

exchanges.description:
The original state before setting up the reservoir has to be classified as module "transformation, from unspecified" due to the fact that various types of flooded ground can be distinguished. The flooded area partly consisted of alpine meadows and grazing land, rarely also villages had to be resettled; often impassable, rocky alpine valleys and gorges were filled with water, where only marginal vegetation and no agricultural use was possible. The definition of the character and the environmental value (e.g. forest, areas with rare mushrooms, moorlands, etc.) of the affected areas were not possible, due to the lack of information.
Regarding reservoir power stations, land (i.e. meadows, moorlands, gravel areas etc.) is mainly occupied by reservoirs. Averaged over the investigated sample and distributed over life time the specific land use amounts to 0.0035 m2a/kWh; the transformation of land amounts to 0.00023 m2/kWh. 
Standard values for landuse are assumed.
Estimation. Data are adopted from the Swiss power plant sample as it stands, therefore uncertainty is increased.

Estimation. For the consumption of lubricating oil during plant operation no data was available. It is assumed that both turbines and run-of-river plants need the same amount of oil hence the information about lubricating oil consumption of run-of-rivers is adopted. A consumption of lubricating oil for turbines of 9 liters per GWh is estimated. With an oil density of 0.84 kg/l this amounts to 0.007 g/kWh. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant.

exchanges.description: Literature value/estimation. The specific turbine water amount is inversely proportional to the average  head. A guidance value says that a hydropower plant can produce 1kWh of electricity with 1 m3 water over a head of 450 m. The ecological relevance of the turbine water amount is that it presents a demonstrative dimension of water being taken from natural water balance for a while.

flow.name: Water, turbine use, unspecified natural origin

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated  value. Hertwich 2013 provides an analysis of greenhouse gas emissions from hydropower plants. 89 data points are available for temperate non-alpine plants, from which the average CO2 and CH4 emissions are calculated.
Hertwich, E.G. 2013. Addressing Biogenic Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Hydropower in LCA. Environmental Sciency&Technology, 47, 9604-9611

flow.name: Methane, non-fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Estimation. The area for the barrage and the power station are assumed to amount to 1% of the total land use. No land use for access roads was taken into account.

Estimation. This dataset is based on data of Swiss reservoir power plants. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant. The information given is based on own assumptions.

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres" comment field.
Reflects range average to best performance.

Estimation. For reservoirs in non-alpine regions, it is assumed that they are not as deep as reservoirs in alpine regions and have a bigger surface. As for the land use, also for the water use a factor 10 in comparison to alpine reservoirs is assumed.
Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres" comment field.
Literature value/calculated value. The needed amount of infrastructure per kWh produced is calculated with the lifetime and the annual net energy production (16500GWh/a).
